This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
Hotel Dragomans in Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.

div.head: The George Nungovich Hotels
div.p: Grand Hotel, Helouan.- Finest and most luxurious Hotel near Cairo. Patronized by Royalty. Moderate charges. Special terms for residents.

Hotel des Bains.- Most comfortable hotel, opposite the Baths. Pension from P.T. 40. Attached to the above hotels and specially reserved for their clients are the Golf Links (18 holes) with English Professional. Own Golf House in the dessert.
Sulphur Bath Establishment.- Sulphur water stronger than any in Europe. Eight European Masseurs and Masseuses. Every modern improvement.

div.head: GORDON HOTEL, KHARTOUM.
div.p: Open in November.

Most comfortable and best appointed Hotel in town. Central situation, affording splendid view. No mosquitoes. Verandah music and varied amusements. Electric Light. Carriages at landing stage at touristsè disposal. Cellar renowned.

div.head: "EGYPT OF THE FUTURE
div.p:
Mr. Dicey's new book, "Egypt of the Future," comes in for some severe criticism in the London Press. The "Evening Standard" remarks: From Mr. Edward Dicey, whose wide knowledge based on intimate study and long experience, entitles him to speak with real authority on Egyptian questions, we should have expected a book more clear, concise, and, we venture to say, reasonable than this "Egypt of the Future." A pessimist, he not only distrusts the present administration, but regards with keen anxiety the future that we have to face. Yet his criticisms of Lord Cromer's benevolent autocracy seem far from convincing, while the solution that he offers, or seems to offferfor he makes no definite statements or proposals on his own accountseems self-contradictory. It is the acknowledged and advertised British Protectorate for which he yearns with a passionate feeling that may have tended to warp cool judgement. Yet he opposes manfully the proposals put forward by Lord Cromer's for con
P & O WEEKLY MAIL and PASSENGER SERVICES P & O
EGYPT to BRINDISI, MARSEILLES & LONDON.
(Special connecting Train Services between Brindisi and London, and between Marseilles and London.)

verting the free hand secured by us under our agreement with France into a genuine reality by the abolition of the capitulatoins, the mixed tribunals, and the other anomalies that were the product of an irregular situation. Call it a Protectorate and Mr. Dicey would be satisfied. But the fact without the title fills him with an apprenhension which is, we hope, almost morbid. He girds at Lord Cromer also for having taken the reins of Egyptian government into his capable hands, and concentrated the power in a class of British officials who alone have succeeded in making the desert fruitful, in relieving the people of monstrous burdens, in bringing Egypt from the verge of bankruptcy to solvency and prosperity, in spreading civilisation, progress, and well-being. He would like to see Egypt governed practically by Egyptians under some scheme "best fitted to render our Protectorate more congenialor perhaps I should say less uncongenial to the Egyptian public than that which has hitcherto been adopted by the British Agency." Yet he is very sensible of the perils of fanatical unrest, he supports entirely the necessary severity in suppressing such incidents as the Denishwai affair, and warns us that Islam will always be opposed to Christendom, and that we must hold Egypt, they key to India, by military occupation. It is very difficult to reconcile these conflicting sentiments. It is surely unreasonable to blame a man in one and the same breath for the blindness which has permitted a dangerous licence to the native Press and the dissemination of political discontent, and for an obstinate disinclination to share authority with Egyptian officials. What kind of an Egypt Mr. Dicey desires is far from clear. His Protectorate would presumbly be somewhat autocratic. Yet his aspirations are towards autonomy. His book is, in fact, a puzzle so far as the Egypt of the future is concerned, and gices us little light and no leading.

As a prophet we cannot understand him; as a critic of the present administration we find him quite unconvincing. It may be that it is to the influence of Nubar Pasha, "the one great statesman, Egyptian or European, I have ever known in Cairo," that may be traced the diversity of views that seems so inconsistent. But it is not probable or possible that confidence in Lord Cromer should be thus shaken, though and impetus may well be given to independent study of the problems of Egypt.

div.head: POSITION OF THE COTTON INDUSTRY.
div.p: Speaking broadly, Lancashire spinners and manufactueres are at the opening of February more deeply sold than at the close of 1906, but in weaving the margin of profit is less than perhaps at any time during the past two years. This applies only to weavers who do not spin their own yearn. The firms who have both spindles and loom are doing very well indeed, and our best outlook for cotton piece goods is India, notably Calcutta. The raw cotton crop there is likely to be about 5,000,000 bales, or a good deal larger than any previous season. This will mean that users on the Continent will not need to buy American kinds of the raw material to makeup for a shortage in Surat and the like. There is every possibility, the "Globe's" Manchester correspondent points out, of a much larger supply of raw cotton for the use of the world than was ever known. An interesting feature this is larger growth of Egyptian cotton this season of excellent quality. Bolton yarns of fine counts are very brisk, some firms being engaged for nearly the whole of next year.

Asile Rudolph,
The Asile Rudolph has received £1 from Mr. Const. P. Triantafillon.
The Brindisi Mall.
The mail for Europe, via Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday.
The Plague,
During the past week five cases of plague have been reported, one at Alexandria, two at Saez, and two in the Mellawi district.
The Petzmazoglu Estate.
According to the Athenian newspapers, Mrs Syngros has made a claim on the estate of the late M. Petzmazoglou for six million drachmæ.
Encounter with Robbers,
An affair with robbers is repo t'from Abou Zaabel. Shots were exchanged between the police and the malefactors, but no harm was done. An erquiry has been opened.
Fatal Acoldent.

Yesterday, a plank fell from a scaffolding in the Bab Sharieb quarter of Cairo, killing a boy oatright. At the end of last week a house collapsed in a lane leading off Clot Bey-Street. Fortunately no one was in doors at the time.
Egyptian Ivory.

At the last quarterly ivory sales held in London, Egyptian, the supply of which was much less than at the previous sales, sold at an advance of 27 to 41 per cwt on soft tuske, hard being firm to 27 per dwt higher. Sori velloes much dearer.
The Egyptian Sudan.

Dr. Wallis Badge, of the British Museum, is bringing out, within the next week or two, through Messrs. Kegan, Paul, a book on "The Egyptian Sadan," which promises to be of exceptional interest, alike from the point of view of archaeology and ethnology. It is the outcome of personal research in the Sudan and is to be fully illustrated.
National Bank,

The National Bank announces a competition among architects resident in Egypt for the plans of the new premises about to be constracted for the Alexandria branch of the Bank. The conditions of this competition, in which two prizes are offered, are contained in a pamphlet which will be procurable at the National Bank in Alexandria after Monday next, 18th inst.
General Court Martial,

No. 4120, Private Fred Wright, 1st Battalion King's Royal R fle Corps, a soldier under sentence in the Detention Barracks, Cairo, was convicted by a General Court Martial at the Citadel, Cairo, on 12th inst., of gross insubordination in the Detention Barracks, and sent enced to penal servitude for three years and discharge with ignominy from His M-jesty's Service. The sentence has been confirmed.
White Star Line.

Tourists making arrangements for the homeward journey would do well to study the Bailings of the White Star Line, which they will find on page 1. The company's S.8. Canopic from Alexandria on March 13, will call at Palermo on March 16 en route for Naples. An excellent opportunity is thus afforded for passengers to visit Sicily direct from Alexandria by a first class ocean steamer.
Attempted Surreptitious Burial,

A Greek man and woman were arrested yesterday evening in the vicinity of Victoria College while they were in the act of attempting to bury the dead body of a child. They were taken to Moharrem Bey Caracol and the child's body was removed to hospital, where a post mortem examination revealed the fact that the child had died from small pox. An enquiry is being held by the police, and meantime the caracol, the dead child's parents, and their house have been disinfected.
Anglo-American Hospital Ball,

At a recent committee meeting of the Anglo- American Hospital, Cairo, it was decided to give a ball in order to raise funds which are argently needed. The ball will be held on Thursday, March 7, at the Casino of the Ghezireh Palace Hotel under the patronage of the Countess of Cromer, Mrs. Iddings, Mrs. Ballock, and other ladies well known in Cairo Society. Tickets of admission (P.T. 100 each) can be P.T. 10 obtained from any of the lady patronesses, the hon. secretary, Major J K. Watson, C.M.G., D.S.Q., Ghezireh Palace Gardens,, Cairo, or the hon. treasurer, Mr. F. H. Russell, Maison Chawarbi Pasha, Kasr el Nil, Cairo.
The Brindisi Route,

It is stated that the reason why the British Government intend to sbandon the Brindisi for the Marseilles route for the Eastern Mails is because the expresses conveying the mails across Italy from Modena to Brindisi have been affected by the general disorganisation of the Italian railway lines, which for a long time past has been a cause of general complaint, and the British Post Office is said to have protested without avail against, the extraordinary delays on the journey. The report has caused commotion at Brindisi, and a meeting was held last Sunday to protest against the Italian Government's inaction in the matter.

div.head: LORD CHAS. BERESFORD.
div.p: RUMOURED RESIGNATION.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Thursday. Lord Charles Beresford's strong disapproval of the proposed redistribution of the Channel Fleet is considered as a basis for an unconfirmed rumour of his resignation.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
div.p: The consultative committee of the Legislalive Council met on Wednesday to discuss the text of the draft decree on the organisation of the police in the Eastern desert. The Committee will meet daily, and transmit the results of its deliberations to the Legislative Council, which will pronounce its opinion on the decree at its meeting of the 20th inst.

div.head: ANGLO-BELGIAN COMPANY OF EGYPT.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.) Medinet-el-Fayoum, Wednesday.

Baron George de Reuter, the chairman of the board of directors of the Anglo-Belgian Company of E ypt, Limited, with M. Frison, a Belgian capitalist, are inspecting the lines or the Fayoum Light Railway, which was, it will be remembered, taken over last year by the Baron's company. Baron de Reuter informed me that the Anglo-Belgian Company intends to make considerable improvements in the Fayoum lines in the near future by laying down new lines and extending the present railway system in this province. The Baron is much interested in the Fayoum and intends turning his attention to this province.
The Fayoum light railway is giving better returns now and many people here believe that this line has a brilliant fatare under its rew management.

div.head: THE MODERN EGYPTIAN.
div.p: Selim writes in "Al Moayad":"I am a partisan of modern civilisation, one of the Europeanised: I prefer a hat to & tarboush. I wont meat gloves, and all his tarhonen. knowing why. I take 5 o'clock tea at Shepheard's and whisky at the Continental. I loathe the Arab theatre and am an abonné at the Opera. Having taken a train on my way home I observed at the end of my seat an old, filthy and disgusting fellah who was devouring dates with amazing celerity and address. I stared at him, whereat he smiled and offered me a handful of dates in his black paw. To me ! who read Victor Hugo, stady Shakespeare. . . . refuse a piastre to a mendicant and pay a franc for a sandwich, am I to accapt them?... W-1, his hands are black-but why? Because they have oultivated the cotton on which I have speculated at the boarse and which enables me to pay for my tea, my whisky, and my scented soap. You can't expect his hands to be white, can you?... And after all the dirty hand that shocks you is finer than your own: and there is something in the poor old man's smile that illuminate: his gesture. His hand is atretched out to give, not to receive. His horny fingers seem to say, "your ancestors thought as I think, their hands were as grimy as mine and the land was theirs. They were frse ander no foreign rale, anthreatened by banks. They were happy! These dates I offer you are the fruit of my toil, watered with the sweat of my brow, and what may you have done to carry a gold-headed cane, at new hat, and a nice pair of gloves? You in. harited-yes, from the grimy han is of the past. You speculated-yes, on my cotton !"

div.head: UPPER NILE RAILWAYS.
div.p: A project is being considered for connecting Victoria Nyanza with Lake Albert by means of electric railways and a service of steamers on Lake Kioja and the Nile. The Ripon Falls will supply an abundance of power, and it is believed that there are no great difficulties in the way of the construction of the railway line. This route would tap the trade of the Congo Free State and bring much traffic to the Uganda railway. The cultivation of cotton is being enthusiastically taken up by the chiefs and other large landowners in Uganda. The exports already amount to 25 tons a week, and the output will assume very large proportions. The cultivation offers great opportunities for the profitable investment of capital in Uganda. Land can be purchased at a very moderate rate, and labour is plentiful and cheap.

div.head: ATBARA LAND SYNDICATE, LTD.
div.p: Mr. Lang Anderson and Mr. J. Hicks Paull are leaving Alexandria for the Sadan on Sunday next in connection with the Atbara Land Syndicate, Limited. Mrs. Lang Anderson and Mrs. J. Hicks Paull will accompany them.

div.head: FIGHT ON TROOPSHIP.
div.p: 300 SOLDIERS JUMP INTO CANAL.
SEVERAL KILLED AND WOUNDED.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)

Port Tewfik, Thursday. A very serious fight took place in the Suez Canal between Syrian and Tarkish soldiers on board the Turkish troopship Hodeidab, bound to Hodeidah with reinforcements. The outcome of it was that 300 men escaped by jumping into the Canal, several of them being shot and drowned. In addition to this, 17 soldiers were seriously wounded, and on arrival at Suez were landed at the quarantine pier for conveyance to Hospital.
The vessel is guarded by police launches pending her sailing, and at present everything seems quiet on board.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S TOUR.
div.p: Our Luxor Correspondent telegraphs that Lord Cromer arrived there yesterday at 8 p.m. and paid a visit to Karnak. His lordship was to have left to-day for the South.

div.head: SIRDAR TO VISIT CAIRO.
div.p: The Sirdar, Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, is expected to arrive in Cairo shortly from the Sudan, in order to confer with Lord Cromer. His Excellency will return to Khartoum after spending a fortnight in the Capital.

div.head: BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.
div.p: The annual general meeting of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt was held yesterday at the offices of Messrs. Carver Bros. & Co., Ltd., Alexandria, with the president, Mr. H. P. Kingham, in the chair. The accounts ard balance-sheet for the year ending the 31st December, 1906, were unanimously adopted, and the following members of the committee, who retired in accordance with the articles of association, were duly re-elected viz, Mr. H.E. Barker, Mr. HP. Kingham, Mr. R. J. Moss, ard Mr. V. Naggiar.
The full text of the President's speech, reviewing the work done by the Chamber during the past year, will appear in to morrow's issne.

Votes of thanks were accorded to the Chamber's honorary legal adviser, Mr. A 8. Preston; to the honorary aaditors, Messrs. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt; and to Messrs. Carver Bros. for their kindness in allowing the use of their offices for committee meetings.

div.head: FATHY BEY ZAGHLOUL.
div.p: Since the departure of Mr. Robertson, M.P., from Egypt the great topic in the vernacular Press has been the appointment of Fathy Bey Zaghloul, and columns and columns' are being written on the subject. Sayid Hassan Moussa el-Akkad, the well-known Cairo Nationalist, in a letter to "Al Minbar" on the subject, declares that the attack on Fathy Bey is pointless, and he ought not to be criticised for his share in the Danishwai trial, for he cannot be considered in any way responsible for the severe sentence. It is well known, says the writer, that the scaffold was made ready for the Denishwai executions before the special court met. "I, for my part," he continues, "would not oppose the appointment of a native to a high position, even though the appointment be made for the purpose of withdrawing him from 'us,' as appears to be the case in this instance. It is far better to leave Fathy Bey to 'them' and try to gain over his heart and sympathy."

div.head: INSPECTION OF KUTTABS.
div.p: Sheikh Moh. Sherif, inspector to the Ministry of Education, has been appointed Chief Inspector of Kattabs. Sheikhs Moh. Nasser and Abd el Rahim Selim have been appointed inspectors.

div.head: SCENE AT GREEK PATRIARCHATE.
div.p: The Orthodox Patriarchal Palace of Alex. andria was yesterday afternoon the scene of unwonted commotion for so usually solemn a place. From what can be gathered it appears that a Greek woman, Kyriaki by name, in the domestic employ of an English family of Ibrahimieb, had gone to the Patriarchate to obtain a decree nisi against her husband, Yoannis Marinitis. Her movements had, however, been watched by her husband, who with a trio of Greek stalwarts, had closely pursued her to the Patriarchate, and before she could reach the registration offi e the men had rushed up the stairway and seized her. She screamed for help, and her ories brought the custodian to her assistance, but he was overpowered and before help could come. Kyriaki was forced into a carriage and driven rapidly away. Since then the Patriarchal officials have ordered a search to be made for her; it is believed that she has been taken to her brother-in-law's. There were several witnesses to this extraordinary abduotion, but not knowing the cause thereof they did not care to intervene.

Yoannis Marinitis is a Soiote, a mason by trade, and he married Kyriaki a year and a half ago on that Island. As he took to drink she separated from him about nine months ago, and had since then been in the employ of this English family. Both are rayahs, or Ottoman subjects, and Orthodox Greeks.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: WATER FAILS AT YAMBO.

A telegram from Jeddah states that the embarkation of pilgrims at Yambo has come to a standstill owing to the want of water. The majority of the pilgrims are shat up at Coucha exposed to the rain (sic).
A death from plague is reported from Jeddah.

div.head: KHEDIVAH-MOTHER'S PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: The Khedivah Mother, it is said, has decided to make the pilgrimage next year. Her High- Doss will be accompanied by her son-in-law, Prince Kamal El-Din Pasha, and his wife.
It is stated that the Khedive has ordered Hussein Pasha to be appointed Emir El-Hag for the next year's pilgrimage.

div.head: INDUSTRIAL BUILDING AND COMMERCIAL COMPANY OF EGYPT LIMITED.
div.p: The subscription for shares in the Industrial" Bailding and Commercial Company of Egypt opened and closed yesterday at Alexandria and Cairo Subscriptions were invited from the public at par for 144,250 ordinary shares of £1 each and it was covered thirty times over. A great number of subscriptions were received from the interior, and the investing public to all appearances have the utmost Confidence in this flotation.

div.head: MR. MACHELL'S TOUR.
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).

Keneh, Tuesday. Mr. Machell, the Adviser, to the Ministry of the Interior, arrived here to-day accompanied by Lady Victoria Machell. On arrival they were met by Mr. Hazell and the Mondir. Mr. Machell drove atraight to his steamer on the Nile, which was awaiting him. After an hour, on board, he, accompanied by Mr. Hazell, drove to the Mondirish. The Adviser inspect ed the Moudirieh and visited the different offices. He also inspected Keneh Markaz, and the prison, which he described as an industrial school owing to the work done by the prisoners. He lunched with the Moudir and afterwards visited the Government school. At 4 o'clock he left by steamer for Luxor, where he will stay for two days.

Our Correspondent telegraphs from Luxor that Mr. Machell arrived there on Wednesday accompanied by Mr. Hazell and inspected the soldiers and ghaffirs of the markaz He was extremely satisfied with the order and tidiness which he found. He left for the South at 7 p.m.

div.head: SEMIRAMIS HOTEL.
div.p: Among the latest arrivals at the Semiramis Hotel we note Comtesse de Montjoy, Baron and Baronne de Menasce, Mr. J. Brooke, Dr. and Mrs Barrach, Mr. and Mrs. Tawil, Comte and Mlle de Revelière, Mr. and Mrs. E. Cahill, Mr. and Mrs. Deufert Sir William and Lady Geary, Kaim. Moberly Bey, M. and Mme Kenna, Capt. and Mrs Thompson, M. J.Vickers, Mr. Vandelin, Capt. and Mrs. Smith.
The small dance on Wednesday evening was well attended. The restaurant and dining room presented a very brilliant appearance, as did the splendid Empire ball-room, which is certainly unique in Cairo.
The Viennese Orchestra performs at the hotel daily daring afternoon tea and dinner. Another dance will be given on Wednesday next.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: Signa. Berlendi scored another big success in "Carmen," of which the second performance was given yesterday. At the risk of repeating ourselves, we must again express our admiration for a most painstaking and entirely successful reading of this ardoons role. Not only was Signa. Berlendi's acting convincing in every detail, but her vocal efforts were proof of her having thoroughly mastered the part. Sig. de Marchi's Don José was also well-nigh faultless; both vocally and dramatically be showed his usual taste and refine. ment, He might with advantage have let himself go a little more in the first two acts, bat he was perfect in the latter half of the opera. Despite these two excellent achievements, the general result obtained was not so good as on Friday last, and for this the orchestra were chiefly responsible; throughout Aots I. and IV. and during most of Act III. there was a want of firmness and spirit. We wish it were realised that vigour is not to be obtained by more unbalanced speed. Sig. Dalbore, as Escamillo, also laboured under this delusion to a certain extent and can hardly be Baid to have fulfilled requirements. Signa. Finzi's Micaela was skilfully and fervently executed; her methods are rather old-fashioned, but all the same very pleasing and suave. The chorus again acquitted themselves very well. In short, "Carmen" is one of the best given of this season's opera, as last night's fall and enthusiastic house amply acknowledged. The opera will be given again to-night.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: FOOTBALL
SMALL UNITS SHIELD.

The final of the Small Units Shield was played at Ghezireh on Tuesday, the teams in the final being the Mounted Police and the Royal Horse Artillery. The ground was in a very good. condition, despite the late rain. The R.H.A. ought to have won, but were defeated by the Mounted Police in a somewhat aninteresting game by two goala to one.
POLO.
LADIES' NOMINATION TOURNAMENT.
SEMI-FINALS.
The matches in the tournament have proved most interesting throughout. The winners of yesterday's matches meet in the final to-
morrow.
RED.
Mr. Fleury 1.
Bowen II,
دو
WHITE.
(Capt. Amery I.
Ld Lanesborough Il.
Sir Walter Barttelot, (back).
Tollemache III. v. Mr. Schreiber III.

Mejor Paterson, (back). The Reds had rather the best of the game throughout, and won by two goals to one. In the first chokker the Reds scored a goal from a good run by Mr. Bowen. In the second cbakker, play was fairly level, no goals being scored by either side. In the third chukker the Rede scored another goal, but were penalized for off-side and shortly afterwards Mr. Schreiber scored for the Whites. In the fourth chakker, the Reds, being penalized for off-side, had to hit out from behind their own line, and Major Paterson made a brilliant ran down the ground. The Whites crossed badly just in front of goal, thereby giving the Reds a shot at goal from which they scored the winning
point.
SECOND MATCH.
RED. Mr. Soames I. Capt. Holland II. Rome 111. Mr. J. Reid (back).
WHITE.
(Mr. Capell I.

Nixon II. Capt. Bartlett III. .. Sterling (back). This was a faster and more exciting game, the Reds ultimately winning by 4 goals to 3. For the winners, Capt. Rome played a brilliant game, and Mr. Reid was fairly sure at back,. but seemed to take a long time turning. For the losers, Capt. Bartlett played splendidly and with a little straighter shooting at goal would have won the match for his side. We look forward to a most interesting final to-morrow.

The tournament for the Sabalterns Cap presented by the Coldstream Guards will commence on Saturday, 16th inst. Seven teams have entered, 3 teams from the Coldstream Guarda, 2 from the Inniskilling Dragoons, one from the King's Own Scottish Borderers, and one from the Dublin Fusiliers, We look forward to a very interesting tournament.

div.head: CONCERT AT THE SAVOY.
div.p: There has been such a remarkable dearth of concerts in Cairo this season that that given by the Marquis Francesco Filiasi and Maestro Vincenzo Cantabi at the Savoy on Wednesday was warmly welcomed both for its novelty and for the intrinsic charm of its programme. It is th the first appearance of both of these artists in Cairo; but they are well known in Naples and have many friends here, including the Count and Countess of Zogheb and the Paravicini's; and it is to be hoped that we may have many other opportunities of deepening the impression they made upon their first appearance among us. The Marquis Francisco Filiasi is a very sympathetic and graceful pianist, and both as soloist and accompanist displayed a charming touch and facility. He also played some of his own compositions, his "Novelletta" and "Mazarka" much merit no little

Maestro Vincenzo Cantani, the violinist, is possessed of a very fine technique and purity of feeling, his playing is singularly correct and facile, but his performance on Wednesday was so restrained as to be lacking in the fire and sympathy necessary to arouse the enthusiasm of his audience. In his last appearance, when he rendered Wieniawsky's delightful "Fantaisie sur Faust," he certainly showed a power of expression which we hope to feel intensified on his next appearance, and which showed that the coldness of his earlier performances was more due to the novelty of his surroundings than any lack of feeling.

We were glad to see that a very fairly numerous and appreciative audience had gathered to welcome these new artists, though as usual the pleasure of a certain portion was much disturbed by the ill-advised condact of a few well-known residents who chose to continue an entirely unnecessary con- versation during the first half of the programme. It is not the first time we have had to dwell upon the thoughtless so'fishness of those who choose to disturb their neighbours in this manner, and we can only hope that if these lines meet the eyes of the offenders they will endeavour in future to keep their conversation for a more appropriate occasion.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Djemily Fasha Toassoun leaves for Europe on the 27th inst.
Major-General G. M. Ballock, C.B., Commanding the Force in Egypt, accompanied by Colonel G. Cathbert, A.A.G., proceeded from Cairo on Wednesday to Edkop on inspection daty.
The Earl of Yarmouth is expected to arrive at Cairo from Nice in a few days.

El Lewa Baron Sir R. von Slatin Pasha left Khartoum on Tuesday week for a trip on the White Nile as far as Hillet Abbas in company of H. R H. the Duke of Brunswick, who arrived in Khartoum on Sunday evening, and was a guest at the Palace.

In the black list of absentee peers compiled from the Lords Journals for the session of 1905, the late Anglo-Egyptian official, Lord Dormer, is among the 179 peers who did not attend on a single occasion.

The latest arrivals at the Hotel d'Angleterre are: the Earl and Countess of Albemarle, Lord Dynewor, Lady Holland, Mr. H. Sowler, Mr. R. de Rustafjaell, Mr. H R. and Lady Norah Hodgson, Comte and Comtesse R. de Castries, Sir John H. Maxwell, Mr. James F. D'Aray, Mr. H. de Ponthiere, Col. and Mrs. Sterel, Major P. G. Graigie, Capt. Owain Greaves, Capt. Hicks, Lient. W. V. Holt, Mr. and Mrs. Wm. Simes, Misses Simer, Mr. and Mrs. H. B. Loomis, Dr. and Mrs. Waldo, Mr. and Mrs. H. W. Kearos, Miss M. Kearns, Mr. and Mrs. M. Schlesinger, Mr. and Mrs. F. G. Bary, Col. and Mrs. J. Ridell.

M. Lagarde, the French Minister to Abyssinia, is making a short stay in Cairo, en route to Marseilles. He is travelling by the S.8. Natal, which is now being repaired at Port Said of the damage she sustained in her recent mishap.

The latest London papers bring the news of the death of General Sir Archibald Alison, whose name will long be remembered in Egypt for the share he took in suppressing Arabi When Arabi Pasha's rebellion occurred in 1889, immediately after the bombardment of Alex. andria, General Alison arrived in Egypt. With at first a very small force, including marines and sailors landed by Sir Beauchamp Seymour from the fleet, under 5,000 men, he took over the occupation and defence of Alexandria. Order was speedily restored, the forts oconpied, and the Egyptian army, which had retired a few miles to escape the cannon of the fleet, sat down and menaced the city. In a short time Sir Archibald, with a mere handful of troops marched out from Moharrem Bey Gate cleared the enemy out of Ramleh, and invited the "Arabists" to come oat from their works at Kafr Dawar and accept battle in front of Melahah Janction. And there were several brisk skirmishes when the honours were with our troops, the left of which rested upon historic ground, where Aberorobie fought and fall.

It was in these scorching, hard working days that Captain John Fisher, now First Sea Lord and Admiral of the Fleet, organised and fought the armour-clad train, and Alison and everybody so repeatedly "trailed their coats" to get a stand-up fight out of Arabi and his men, When the great turning movement was made by Wolseley to Ismailia, General Alison led the Highland Brigade at Tel el Kebir. He was in front of his men on that trying night march of Sept. 13. 1882, and at their head just as dawn was coming. Sword in hand, he showed them the way to the "Arabist" forts, works, and trenches, and roaring, "Charge!" still as leader struck like an irresistible avalanche of steel and blood the astounded Egyptians. Cheering and yelling, the Highlanders swept over the enemies' works, thrusting all opposition aside with their bayonets. The grand, picturesque soldier scrambled to the parapet of one of the forte, and from there gave directions that helped to secure the swiftest and most decisive victory of all modern wars. Subsequently Sir Archibald was for about a year in command of the troops left in Egypt.

Among the passengers who left by the S.S. Osmanieh on Wednesday ware Mr. H. F. Shoemaker and Miss Shoemaker, Mr. and Mrs. 8. Harper, Mr. B. Lawer, Mr. and Mrs. Loth, Mr. A. Haywood, and Mr. A. Thompson. Mr. A. Thom

Sayid Abdallah El Mamour El-Sahrawardi, President of the lelamic Union in London, has arrived in Cairo, and is leaving shortly for India, where he intends to practise as a lawyer, and publish an Anglo-Indian newspaper.

ABRIDGED PROSPECTUS

This Company has been formed for the purposes set forth in the Memorandum of Association to carry on business in Egypt, the Sudan and Cyprus, and more particularly to at once acquire certain Freehold Land situate at Ghezireh near Cairo.

The Directors have been fortunate in securing a plot of land of about 10,000 square metres forming part of the Estate of the Ghezireh Palace Hotel, and known as the Harem Buildings, situated at the immediate approach to the new Boulac Bridge at Ghezireh and having a large frontage on the new tramway route which will lead direct to the Pyramids. Upon completion of the Bridge, passengers will be able to take a tram from the centre of Cairo over the New Bridge direct to the Pyramids and there is no doubt that when this important work is finished, there will be a great augmentation of passenger and vehicular traffic to and from the Pyramids and Ghizireh.

This Company has secured the valuable and sole Monopoly of being able to build shops on the estate, therefore all the trade in this rapidly rising Suburb must necessarily be confined to those who have the privilege of becoming tenants or purchasers of the plots. The Company has also secured the right to build shops and houses to a height of 20 metres this being 2 metres higher than the height allowed to any previous purchasers, which is a privilege of considerable value to this Company.

The Ghezireh Estate was owned by the late Khedive, Ismail Pacha, who built the present Palace and made it his principal residence. It is now the property of the "Egyptian Hotels Limited" and is called the Ghezireh Palace Hotel , which is one of the most luxurious Hotels to be found anywhere.

The property to be purchased, besides the advantages stated above of being opposite the approach to the new Boulac Bridge, has the most delightful surroundings, being situated in the centre of the well-known Ghezireh Gardens, adjoining which are the Khedivial Sporting Club, the Race course and the Grotto. This district is already a fashionable quarter for the wealthy classes and the increased facilities of access from Cairo must necessarily tend to increase the residential population.

Hitherto no villas have been erected at lower rentals than L250 to L300 per annum and permission was given to build on only 1/3rd of the area of each plot, in consequence of which and also owing to the difficulty of access to and from Cairo, the cost of living in the neighbourhood has been very high.

The Egyptian Hotels Company, Limited, being desirous of developing their Estate as rapidly as possible and with a view to providing increased facilities to Residents, have granted to this Company the sole right to erect shops as well as houses. The building of these shops should ensure a considerable increase in the number of Residents and be of great advantage to the neighborhood, and a substantial source of revenue to the Company.

Applications for Shares should be made on the accompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company's Bankers. If no allotment is made, the application money will be returned in full, and where the number of shares allotted is less than that applied for the surplus will be credited in reduction to the amount payable on allotment, and any excess will be returned to the Applicant.
Failure to pay any installment when due will render the previous payments liable to be forfeited.
The minimum subscription upon which the Directors may proceed to Allotment has been fixed by the Articles of Association at £70,000.
A brokerage of three pence per Share will be paid to Brokers on all Shares applied for and allotted to the public on Application, Forms bearing their stamps.
Copies of this Prospectus and Application Forms can be obtained at the Local Offices of the Company, and from the Company's Bankers.
Dated the 13th February 1907.

div.head: Egyptian Salt & Soda Coy., Ltd.
div.p: The Directors of the Egyptian Salt & Soda Company, Ltd , have decided to issue at par 50,000 new ordinary shares of £1 (one ponud sterling) each to rank pari-passu with existing ordinary shares. The new shares are now offered by preference to Holders of the 450,000 existing ordinary shares, and will be allotted to applicants in the proportion of one new share for every complete nine old shares. Forms of application can be obtained from the Company's Bankers, the National Bank of Egypt, in Cairo, Alexandria or London.

Holders of share warrants to bearer wishing to exercise their right to subscribe must present their warrants to the Company's Bankers for verification and stamping from the 18th to 20th February 1907 together with application for the new shares and the sum of 10/- (ten shillings) per share applied for.The balance of 10/- (ten shillings) per share must be paid on or before 20th March 1907. Share Warrants to bearer will be issued to Allottees in respect of fully-paid sharesunpon application, and payment of stamp duties.
Registeted Share Holders should make application direct to the Secretaty at the Registered Office of the Company, 6 Old Jewry, London, E.C.

Applications for new shares must be received by the Company's Bankers or by the Company itself, as the case maybe, not later than 20th February 1907 after which date the Directors will allot any new shares not applied for, to such persons as they may deem fit.

div.head: Cairo Electric Railways and Helipolis Oases Co.
div.p: Service of Motor Buses from Aggassieh to 1st Heliopolis Oasis.
Starting from today a service of motor buses will run between Abbassiah and the first Oasis of Heliopolis, connecting with the Abbassieh Tramway line of Cairo.
The buses will leave the tramway terminus (Abbassieh line) every hour from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m.

On the return journey departures will take place every hour, from the Palace Hotel of the First Oasis, beginning at 7:30 a.m., 8:30, 9:30 and so on until 5:30 p.m. Single fares 5 milliemes outside, and 10 milliemes inside. There will be no return tickets.
The following are the stations to Heliopolis: Abbassieh Terminus, Military Hospital and Hotel. Return, Hotel, Military Hospital, Abbassieh Terminus.

div.p: M.M. les proprietaries d'immeublesbatis situes a Alexandrie et dans sa banlieue, sont informes que, en execution de l'art. 11 du Decret du 13 Mars 1884, les roles d'impositicn pour l'exercice 1907 dresses en vertu et en conformite des Decrets du 13 Mars 1884 et 11 Avril 1886, ont ete arretes et rendus executiores a partir du 15 Fevrier 1907.

Les roles d'imposition comprennent les constructions imposes en 1899 et don't les huit annees sont revolues sinsi que celles nouvellement construites et achevees en 1906; ces roles sont deposes a la Municipalite au Service des Recettes, au les proprietaries pourront eu prendre connaissance.

Les roles d'imposition sont mis en recouvrement et chaque contribuable doit payer le montant de l'impot dent il est redevable, sous peine d'y etre constraint, en conformite de l'article 14 du Decret du 13 Mars 1884.

L'impot est payable par trimester d'avance contre des recus emanants du Service des Recettes portant le cachet du Directeur du Service et la signature du percepteur charge du recouvrement pour chaque immeuble separement.

Les reclamations a formeler devant le Conseil de revision contres les operations du recensement, devront etre presentees jusqu'au 14 Mai 1907 pour les proprieter lont les buit ans sont revolus et 14 Aout 1907 pour Jes constructions nouvelles.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demie.)

Beaucoup de bruit pendant tonte la seance, mais peu d'affaires. Apres un recul de toute la cote, on s'est ressaisi en cloture sur un certain nombre de valeurs; mais il n'en est pas moins vrai que, comme ensemble, c'est la baisse qui predomine.
Les affaires se sont limitees aux Karam, Ritz, Salt & Soda, Cassa di Sconto, Nungovich Hotels, Estates, Urbaine, Comptoir, Building et Credit Franco- Egyptien.

A signaler une reprise du Comptoir sur le bruit que M. Zervudachi serait appele a faire partie du Conseil d'administration, et une baisse de la Building par suite des ventes effectuees par un gros detenteur.

Bien qu'il n'ait ete vendu aucune action Splendid Hotels depuis deux ou trois jours, quelques interesses s'amusent en cloture a faire baisser la cote d'un point chaque jour. Ils peuvent continuer sans faire de tort a personne.
Le marasme dans lequel se debat actuellement notre marche provient des nouvelles emissions, de l'abstention des capitalistes se rieux et de l'attitude reservee des banques.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Jeudi 14 Fevrier 1907. Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres se tient a 4 3/4, en attendant une neuvelle reduction, car on prevoit que la Banque d'Angleterre ne tardera pas a abaisser son taux a 4 1/2, voire a 4%. Le bilan hebdomadaire publie avant-hier par cette institution montre, en effet, une amelioration marquante: la re serve des billets s'est accrue de £1,076,000 et l'encaisse de £224,000. La proportion de la reserve aux engagements s'est eleves a 49 5/8 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, ie Consolide anglais s'est maintenu a 87 1/8 et l'Unifiee a 103 3/4. La National Bank a gagne 1/4 a 28 5/8. Par contre, l'agricole est renseignee, sauf erreur, en reaction de 1/4 a 9 8/4, de neme que la Daira a 17 1/2. La Deita Light a avance de 3/8 a 11 7/8.
A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptien a retro grade de 2 francs a 776. La Banque d'Athenes a regagne 1 frano a 136.

Ici, la tendance generale continue a rester bonne, mais tonjours aveo des affaires restreintes sur l'ensemble de la cote par suite des retards apportes a la de ente monetaire par le flot croissant des nouvelles emission. Il est a croire, heureusement, que ces appes de fouds fastidieux fiuiront par passer iuapercus, cequi permettra au marche de s'orienter et d'operer les mouvements naturels en cetre periode active de l'annee.
Lea seuls traits caracteristiques de la seance ont ete avaances de la National Bank, une nouvelle poussee vigoureuse sur les Nungovich et une hausse marquante sur les Suburban (Demerduche).

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la NationaL en bonne demande, a atteint 28 1/2 pour cotorer a 28 3/8 7/16. L'Agricole ne gligee, a molli a 9 15/16 10. La Casaa di Sconto a faibli a 277-278. Le Comptoir Financier est remonte a 7 9/ 6-5/8.
Le Credit Foncier a ete delaisse a 771; l'obligation a lots 1886 s'est tassee a 345-346. La Nile Land a faibli a 23.
L'Immobiliere a gague 6 francos a 390. L'Enterprise and Development a progresse a 13 7/8. L'Allotment a avance a 3 1/2 9/16; sa part s'est inscrite a 135.
Les Entreprises Immobilieres et Travaux ont coure a 12 14 et leur part a 238. L'Epargne Immobil ere a ete negociee a 3 5/16 et sa part a 240. L'Express Nile a ete traitee a 6-6 1/8 et sa part a 340.
Les Suburban, en bonne demande ont atteint 6 7/8 pour terminer a 6 11/16.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hotelieres, les Nungovich, poursuivant leur mouvement de hausse, ont gagne environ une livre a 26 7/8-15/16; on parle de l'existence d'un decouvert. Les Egyptian ont ete moins bien tenus a 12 5/8-11/16. Les Excelsior sont restes a 4 11/16 et les National a 3 3/4-13/16; il y a lieu d'observer les cours de ces titres a raison des assemblees extraordinaires des deux Societes, announcees pour le 12 et le 13 du courant.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'est maintennue a 4 3/8. Les Estates se sont raffermis a 2 5/8; leur part a beneficie d'une livre a 22 7/8 23. Les Salt and Soda ont avance a 23 sh. et les New Egyptian a 30 sh. 7 1/2. Les Constructions ont flechi a 1 3/8.
Les nouvelles emissions:
On en annonuce deux pour le cours de la semaine prochaine, en attendant les autres:

1 Celle de l"Industrial, Building and Commercial Company of Egypt, au capital de £500,000 represente par 499,375 actions ordinaires a £1 et 12,500 parts de fondateur a 1 shelling. Il est offert en souscription publique 144,250 actions au pair.
2 Celle de la Ghezireh Mansions Ltd. au capital de £200,000, divise en au ant d'actions a £. Le public est invite a souscrire a 48,743 actions au pair.
Vendront ensuite: callas de la Nile Transport Co. (£10,000); de la Bacque S'Escompte et de Reports (£500,000); de l'Omnium Financial (£100,000) etc., etc., etc.
Carnet de l'actionnare:

O announce que, dans sa reunion da 28 Javier derarer Loadres le consei d'administration offre la Work and Memarachi Ltd decide de proposer un dividende de 5% pour Pexercice 906 soit 1 shelling par scimi de £1 - Le souscription au 50,000 actions uouveles Les Egyptian Markets Ltd sera coverte le 11 Fevrer couraut a l'Anglo Egpytian Bank et coturee 18 du meme mois. Les detenteurs actueis peuvent excerer leur droit de preference a raison de 2 actions nouvelles, emises a £1.76 pour 5 actions anciennes.

—Une assemblee generale ordinaire et extra-ordinaire de la Sociere Fonciere d'Egypte est convaquee pour le jeudi 28 Fevrier courant, a 3 h. p.m., au siege social au Caire. I s'agit, entre autres, de deliherer au sujet d'une proposition de remboursement a faire sur les actions au moyen d'une partie des benefices, et au sujet d'une proposition de reduction du capital social.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS.
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In chosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

div.head: SALSOMAGGIORE
div.p: A pleasantly situated village lying in the valley between Piacenza and Parma, rapidly becoming famous for its waters, which are very rich in bromine and iodine and the richest in the world in lithium, strontium, and ichthyol, and have been successfully used in the treatment of scrofula, rheumatism, tuberculous affections, ladies complaints, etc.

This depends party upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest placae to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co's steamers, which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is machto interest the visitor The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless source of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain- his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic orgin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Erimiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay- Castellamare and Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding county. In Florence itself the chruchs and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promendares and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cogwheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY.
div.p: GENOA (La Superba). — The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature— warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble calumns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santa filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern ltaly before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs change trains at Borgo San Dumino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.p: The steamers of the P. & 0., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P & O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste-Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours' journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach the Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other seaport. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como, and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Aro nd it rise M San Salvatore, M. de Caprino and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and "The Flight into Egypt," by Bramanfion.
LUCERNE —A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne to Fluelen is a source of dlelight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunuen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and reciperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concerts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERLAND.— INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort,and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessback, Trummelback and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft. above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, suarounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara. for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is wortn while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail hooting to be had.
mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They ard called the "Ferry boats," having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should' arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.p: LIDO (Venice), VENICE From Venice or Lido, charming trip on the lagoon, 12 min. by steamboat. CLIMATIC STATION AND SEA BATHS, WITH CHINESITHERAPIC INSTITUTE. Express between the Station and Lido for the Hotels.
BAGNI LIDO (Venice). The most important bathing station in Italy. Cafe-Restaurant and Terrace on the sea. Hydrotherapic Institute. Concerts daily. Frequented by the hights classes of society.
GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS.
Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependicies & Chalets. 200 rooms & saloons. Electric light. Aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.
THE GRAND HOTEL, LIDO.

Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel), in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes', walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the Lagune of Venice. Room from 3 lire, with borad from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos Very dry and safe air.
Address-SOCIETE BAGNI, LIDO, VENICE, ITALY.
